1  STATUTORY FRAMEWORK 
2  46.  Congress established the Temporary Protected Status (“TPS”) program through the 
3  Immigration Act of 1990.1 TPS is a form of humanitarian relief, providing lawful immigration 
4  status to eligible foreign nationals who cannot safely return home to war-torn or disaster-stricken 
5  countries. By enacting the TPS statute, which is codified at 8 U.S.C. § 1254a, Congress 
6  established formal criteria for relief and set forth predictable procedures.2 
7  47.  Under the TPS statute, the Secretary of Homeland Security3 makes a “designation” 
8  determination for a given country. After consulting with “appropriate” government agencies, the 
9  Secretary may designate a foreign state, or any part of that state, for TPS based on: (A) an 
10  “ongoing armed conflict within the state” that would “pose a serious threat” to the “personal 
11  safety” of the foreign nationals of that state; (B) an “earthquake, flood, drought, epidemic, or other 
12  environmental disaster in the state resulting in a substantial, but temporary, disruption of living 
13  conditions,” which makes the foreign state “unable, temporarily, to handle adequately the return to 
14  the state” of its nationals, and where the foreign state has “officially” requested a designation; or 
15  (C) the existence of “extraordinary and temporary conditions in the foreign state” that prevent 
16  foreign nationals from safely returning, and where the temporary presence of those foreign 
17  nationals in the United States is not “contrary to the national interest of the United States.”4 
18  48.  An initial designation period for a given country lasts between six and eighteen 
19  months.5 Before the designation can become effective, the Secretary must publish a notice in the 
20

23  “parole power,” which is currently codified at 8 U.S.C. § 1182(d)(5)). Presidents have 
occasionally exercised their discretion to designate countries for “Extended Voluntary Departure” 
24  and “Deferred Enforced Departure.” Somewhat like TPS, both of those delayed-departure 
practices allowed foreign nationals to lawfully remain and work in the United States while 
25  conditions in their homeland were unsafe or return was impracticable.

1  Federal Register that includes, among other things, a statement of findings, the effective date of 
2  the designation, and a tally of eligible foreign nationals. 
3  49.  Once the Secretary has designated a particular country for TPS, individuals from 
4  that country (or persons without nationality who last habitually resided in that country) may apply 
5  for immigration status under the program. To be eligible for TPS, however, individuals from a 
6  designated country must meet stringent requirements. These requirements include, among other 
7  things, continued physical presence and continued residence in the United States from the most 
8  recent date of designation; satisfaction of the criteria for admissibility as an immigrant; lack of 
9  disqualifying criminal history; and submission of an application, extensive documentation, and 
10  fees.6 
11  50.  Congress ensured that individuals who are ultimately granted protected status could 
12  enjoy the freedom to live and work in the United States without fear of deportation. Under the 
13  statute, as enacted by Congress, an individual who receives and maintains TPS shall be authorized 
14  to engage in employment in the United States; shall not be detained by the Secretary of Homeland 
15  Security on the basis of immigration status; and shall not be removed from the United States by 
16  the Department of Homeland Security.7 
17  51.  Under the TPS statute, the Secretary must periodically re-evaluate country 
18  designations. At least 60 days before a particular designation expires, the Secretary must “review 
19  the conditions in the foreign state . . . for which a designation is in effect” and determine whether 
20  the country still meets the conditions for TPS.8 If the Secretary does not terminate TPS for a 
21  particular country, then—by default—the designation will be extended for a period of six months, 
22  or by discretion of the Secretary, for a period of twelve or eighteen months.9 This periodic-review 
23  requirement also entails consultation with appropriate government agencies and, ultimately, 
24  publication of notice in the Federal Register.

1  52.  The TPS statute requires, or, alternatively, permits the Secretary to consider 
2  intervening events—i.e. events occurring after the initial designation—during the periodic review 
3  process, without regard to whether they are directly related to the crisis that triggered the country’s 
4  initial TPS designation.  
5  53.  When a designation for a particular country is terminated, the individual TPS 
6  holder’s status will typically revert back to his or her original immigration status.10 
7  54.  In the event of a designation or extension of a designation, USCIS establishes 
8  periods for registration or re-registration. 8 C.F.R. § 244.17(a). The failure to register or re-register 
9  within a designated time period results in the loss of TPS status. 8 U.S.C. § 1254a(c)(3)(C); 8 
10  C.F.R. §§ 244.14(a)(3), 244.17. Historically, the agency’s practice has been to require TPS 
11  holders to re-register during the period immediately before the effective date of termination of the 
12  existing status (i.e., the date of expiry of their TPS-related documentation and employment 
13  authorization). See, e.g., 71 Fed. Reg. 54,300, 54,302 (Sept. 14, 2006) (registration period until 
14  Nov. 13, 2006 for Burundi extension otherwise expiring on Nov. 2, 2006); 81 Fed. Reg. 44,646, 
15  44,646 (July 8, 2016) (registration period until Sept. 6, 2016 for El Salvador extension otherwise 
16  expiring on Sept. 9, 2016).  
17  55.   On information and belief, this practice is in keeping with the near-universal 
18  practice for comparable re-registration periods. For example, if an individual wants to renew a 
19  driver’s license, that individual must do so during some period shortly before the existing license 
20  expires, not at some other period that ends long before the license expires.  
21  56.  The TPS statute provides that DHS may require payment of a “reasonable fee” not 
22  to exceed $50 for the registration of new applicants subject to new TPS designations. 8 U.S.C. 
23  § 1254a(c)(1)(B), 8 U.S.C. § 1254a(c)(1)(A)(iv). USCIS may not charge the initial registration fee 
24  for the renewal of TPS for existing TPS holders. 8 C.F.R. §§ 244.17(a).

3  61.  In order “to get to the President/White House’s desired result of terminating TPS,” 
4  President Trump’s political surrogates within DHS made numerous changes to TPS practices.16 
5  Most significantly, under their leadership, DHS adopted a new, novel—and legally erroneous—
6  interpretation of the TPS statute that precluded consideration of intervening events during the 
7  periodic review process. 
8  62.  Pursuant to this new, erroneous interpretation of the TPS statute, DHS abandoned a 
9  long-established practice under which it considered all current conditions—including intervening 
10  events—in deciding whether to extend or terminate a country’s TPS designation. In its place, DHS 
11  adopted a new, narrow practice in which DHS considers only whether the original conditions that 
12  initially gave rise to the TPS designation persist, and only those ongoing harms directly tied to 
13  those original conditions.  
14  63.  Before the Trump Administration, for at least twenty years, Republican and 
15  Democratic Administrations alike regularly relied on intervening factors arising after a country’s 
16  original TPS designation to extend TPS. Secretaries considered the full range of current country 
17  conditions in making TPS decisions, regardless of whether those conditions traced back to the 
18  event that triggered the original designation.  
19  64.  Under the Trump Administration, in contrast, extensions would be permitted only 
20  when warranted by the continued effects of the original event triggering the TPS designation.  
21  65.  In June 2017, then-Secretary Kelly described the new standard. He testified at a 
22  Senate hearing that DHS could only consider the original reason for a country’s designation when 
23  recommending extension or termination. He explained that, in the Administration’s view, TPS “is 
24  for a specific event”—for instance, an earthquake in Haiti—“and that’s how I have to look at it.”17

19  incoherence which read like different people drafted the analysis and the recommendations.42 The 
20  memo was then “repackage[d]”43 several more times before ultimately being revised “to clearly 
21  support the . . . decision to terminate.”

1  214.  Individual Plaintiffs seek to represent the following nationwide class: The U.S. 
2  citizen children, from ages five to eighteen, of all TPS holders from El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, 
3  Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan. 
4  215.  The proposed class satisfies the requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
5  23(a)(1) because it is so numerous that joinder of all members is impracticable. 
6  216.  On information and belief, there are tens of thousands of U.S. citizen children of 
7  TPS holders from El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan. Given the dates of 
8  TPS designations for those countries, thousands of those children are from ages five to eighteen 
9  confronted with the possibility of losing either the ability to live in their country or the care and 
10  support of a TPS-holder parent. 
11  217.  Due to the actions of Defendants, the U.S. citizen children of TPS holders will be 
12  forced to choose between their absolute and fundamental due process right to reside in this 
13  country, and their due process right to the care and support of their parents. 
14  218.  The class meets the commonality requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
15  23(a)(2). Members of the class are subject to a common practice or policy: Defendants’ adoption 
16  of a new rule that caused the termination of the TPS designations for their parents’ respective 
17  countries without any consideration of the impact on the class members—i.e., these U.S. citizen 
18  children—or any valid reason justifying the harm that decision imposes on them. When the TPS 
19  terminations were issued, these children were forced by law to choose between their right to reside 
20  in this country as citizens, and their right to reside with their parents. Whether the Due Process 
21  Clause permits the government to force these children into that choice presents a common legal 
22  question, resolution of which will greatly aid the efficient resolution of this case. 
23  219.  The proposed class meets the typicality requirements of Federal Rule of Civil 
24  Procedure 23(a)(3) because the claims of the representative Individual Plaintiffs are typical of the 
25  claims of their class. Individual Plaintiffs and the proposed Citizen-Children Class members are 
26  the school-aged children, from ages five to eighteen, who are U.S. citizens. Their parents will be 
27  subject to removal once the TPS termination decisions take effect. Individual Plaintiffs and their

5  defending their own rights, Individual Plaintiffs will defend the rights of all proposed class 
6  members fairly and adequately. 
7  221.  Additionally, the proposed class is represented by pro bono counsel from the 
8  American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California, the American Civil Liberties Union of 
9  Southern California, Unemployed Workers United, the UCLA Law School Center for 
10  Immigration Law and Policy, and Sidley Austin LLP. Plaintiffs’ counsel have extensive 
11  experience litigating class action lawsuits and other complex cases in federal court, including civil 
12  rights lawsuits on behalf of non-citizens. 
13  222.  The members of the class are readily ascertainable through Defendants’ records. 
14  223.  Finally, the proposed class satisfies Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(1)(A) and 
15  (b)(2). Competing rulings as to whether Defendants must permit the TPS-holding parents of U.S. 
16  citizen children to reside in the United States could create inconsistent adjudications and establish 
17  incompatible standards of conduct governing Defendants’ behavior. In addition, Defendants have 
18  acted on grounds that are generally applicable to the class by terminating the TPS designations for 
19  El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan without considering the massive harm 
20  that decision causes to U.S. citizen children or providing reasons to justify that harm. Thus, final 
21  injunctive and declaratory relief is appropriate for the class as a whole. 
22  CLAIMS FOR RELIEF 
23  FIRST CLAIM 
24  Violation of the Equal Protection Guarantee of the  
25  Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment 
26  (Against All Defendants by All Plaintiffs) 
27  224.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained 
28  in the preceding paragraphs. 
63 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 67 of 75
 
1  225.  The Fifth Amendment contains an implicit guarantee of equal protection that 
2  invalidates any official action that in part reflects a racially discriminatory intent or purpose. 
3  Classifications based on race or national origin receive exacting scrutiny, and even facially neutral 
4  policies and practices will be held unconstitutional when they reflect a pattern unexplainable on 
5  grounds other than race. Bolling v. Sharpe, 347 U.S. 497, 499 (1954); Vill. of Arlington Heights v. 
6  Metro. Hous. Dev. Corp., 429 U.S. 252, 265–66 (1977). 
7  226.  Defendants’ decisions to terminate the TPS designations for El Salvador, Haiti, 
8  Honduras, Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan are unconstitutional because they were motivated, at least 
9  in part, by intentional discrimination based on race, ethnicity, or national origin. 
10  227.  Plaintiffs will suffer irreparable injury resulting from the arbitrary termination of the 
11  TPS designations. Although the TPS termination decisions for El Salvador, Honduras, Nepal, and 
12  Nicaragua themselves are now rescinded, and there are new TPS designations for Haiti and Sudan, 
13  Plaintiffs continue to suffer stigmatic harm from the racial animus that motivated the terminations 
14  and Defendants’ failure to repudiate them. 
15  SECOND CLAIM 
16  Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment 
17  (Against All Defendants by All TPS-Holder Plaintiffs) 
18  228.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained 
19  in the preceding paragraphs. 
20  229.  The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution provides 
21  that “[n]o person shall be . . . deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law.” 
22  U.S. Const. amend. V.  
23  230.  Due process protections extend to “all ‘persons’ within the United States, including 
24  [non-citizens], whether their presence here is lawful, unlawful, temporary, or permanent.” 
25  Zadvydas v. Davis, 533 U.S. 678, 693 (2001). TPS holders are lawfully present in this country. 
26  They have significant liberty interests, protected by the Due Process Clause, in a non-arbitrary 
27  decision as to the continuation of their TPS status. 
28 
64 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 68 of 75
 
1  231.  The “very essence” of due process is the “protection of the individual against 
2  arbitrary action.” Bd. of Regents of State Colls. v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 584 (1972). Any 
3  deprivation of liberty or property interests must, at the very least, pass a test of rationality. The 
4  burden on the government is greater when, as here, the liberty interests at stake derive from well-
5  established and significant reliance interests. 
6  232.  The government has not articulated, and cannot establish, any rational basis for 
7  reversing course on decades of established TPS policy and ignoring the current capability of TPS 
8  countries to safely receive longtime TPS holders, their families, and their U.S. citizen children. 
9  233.  Plaintiffs will suffer irreparable injury resulting from the arbitrary termination of the 
10  TPS designations.  
11  THIRD CLAIM 
12  Violation of the Administrative Procedure Act 
13  (Against All Defendants by All TPS-Holder Plaintiffs) 
14  234.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained 
15  in the preceding paragraphs. 
16  235.  The Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 551 et seq., ensures that federal 
17  agencies are accountable to the public by providing a “right of review” to any “person suffering 
18  legal wrong because of agency action, or adversely affected or aggrieved by agency action.” 5 
19  U.S.C. § 702. Judicial review is generally limited to “final agency action for which there is no 
20  other adequate remedy in a court.” 5 U.S.C. § 704. 
21  236.  Among other things, the APA empowers the federal courts to “hold unlawful and set 
22  aside agency actions, finding, and conclusions” that are “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of 
23  discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). The right of review 
24  under the APA includes a right to judicial review of “executive agency action for procedural 
25  correctness.” FCC v. Fox Television Stations, Inc., 556 U.S. 502, 513 (2009).   
26  237.  To engage in procedurally appropriate decision-making, an agency must ordinarily 
27  “display awareness that it is changing position,” and may not “depart from a prior policy sub 
28  silentio.” Id. at 515. The APA requires an agency to provide “more detailed justification” when 
65 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 69 of 75
 
1  “its new policy rests upon factual findings that contradict those which underlay its prior policy,” 
2  or “its prior policy has engendered serious reliance interests.” Id. 
3  238.  Defendants’ termination of the TPS designations for El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, 
4  Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan constitutes “final agency action for which there is no other adequate 
5  remedy in a court” pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 704, because the Defendants’ termination results in the 
6  TPS holders’ loss of TPS “automatically and without further notice or right of appeal,” 8 C.F.R. 
7  § 244.19. 
8  239.  Defendants’ adoption of a new, drastically narrower interpretation of the TPS statute 
9  was arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law in violation of the APA because it represented a 
10  sudden and unexplained departure from decades of decision-making practices and ordinary 
11  procedures. By shifting the decision-governing standard for country designations without 
12  explanation, Defendants have ignored a clear statutory command and engaged in procedurally 
13  flawed decision-making. Further, Defendants changed their policy without taking into account the 
14  serious reliance interests that their prior policy had engendered. 
15  240.  Plaintiffs will suffer irreparable injury resulting from the arbitrary termination of the 
16  TPS designations, and Defendants’ continued failure to repudiate the narrow interpretation of the 
17  TPS statute they previously adopted without explanation. 
18  FOURTH CLAIM 
19  Violation of the Administrative Procedure Act 
20  (Against All Defendants by All TPS-Holder Plaintiffs) 
21  241.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every 
22  allegation contained in the preceding paragraphs. 
23  242.  Defendants’ interpretation of the TPS statute to preclude consideration of 
24  intervening events was “not in accordance with law,” in violation of 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A) because 
25  the TPS statute does not prohibit the Secretary from considering intervening events when 
26  determining whether to extend TPS. 
27 
28 
66 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 70 of 75
 
1  243.  Plaintiffs will suffer irreparable injury resulting from the legally erroneous 
2  termination of the TPS designations, and face the possibility of future injury from Defendants’ 
3  failure to repudiate the legally erroneous interpretation they previously adopted. 
4  FIFTH CLAIM 
5  Violation of the Administrative Procedure Act 
6  (Against All Defendants by All TPS-Holder Plaintiffs) 
7  244.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained 
8  in the preceding paragraphs. 
9  245.  Defendants’ decision to impose re-registration deadlines that expire long before the 
10  current TPS extensions expire, contrary to all historical practice in the administration of TPS, was 
11  “arbitrary, capricious, [and] an abuse of discretion” in violation of 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). 
12  246.  Due to these arbitrary and capricious registration deadlines, Plaintiffs will suffer 
13  irreparable injury, and many thousands of TPS holders will be deprived of TPS status for which 
14  they are otherwise eligible.  
15  SIXTH CLAIM 
16  Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment 
17  (Against All Defendants by All TPS-Holder Plaintiffs) 
18  247.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained 
19  in the preceding paragraphs. 
20  248.  Defendants’ adoption of re-registration deadlines that expire long before the current 
21  TPS extensions expire is so lacking in justification and contrary to past practice that it fails to 
22  satisfy the rationality constraints imposed by the Fifth Amendment on governmental decision-
23  making in this context. 
24  249.  Due to these arbitrary and capricious registration deadlines, Plaintiffs will suffer 
25  irreparable injury, and many thousands of TPS holders will be deprived of TPS status for which 
26  they are otherwise eligible. 
27  SEVENTH CLAIM 
28  Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment 
67 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 71 of 75
 
1  (Against All Defendants by All U.S. Citizen Children Plaintiffs) 
2  250.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference each and every allegation contained 
3  in the preceding paragraphs. 
4  251.  The Fifth Amendment guarantee against the deprivation of liberty without due 
5  process bars the government from infringing on certain “fundamental” liberty interests, regardless 
6  of the procedures involved, unless the action is “narrowly tailored to serve a compelling state 
7  interest.” Reno v. Flores, 507 U.S. 292, 301–02 (1993). 
8  252.  Three such fundamental rights are implicated here. First, the plaintiffs here who are 
9  school-aged U.S. citizens have an absolute right to live in the United States. To compel them to 
10  live abroad at any time, let alone in their formative years, would deny them a core aspect of their 
11  liberty protected by the Fifth Amendment. See, e.g., Nguyen v. I.N.S., 533 U.S. 53, 67 (2001); Ng 
12  Fung Ho v. White, 259 U.S. 276, 284 (1922). 
13  253.  Second, for at least so long as these U.S. citizen plaintiffs remain school-aged, they 
14  have a fundamental right protected by both the First and Fifth Amendments to live with and be 
15  raised by their parents. E.g., Moore v. City of East Cleveland, 431 U.S. 494, 499 (1977); Board of 
16  Dirs.of Rotary Intern. v. Rotary Club, 481 U.S. 537, 545 (1987). 
17  254.  Third, the government’s decision to end the lawful immigration status of their 
18  parents impinges upon the U.S. citizen plaintiffs’ constitutionally-protected liberty interests. These 
19  U.S. citizen children have a powerful interest in not being compelled to choose between two 
20  alternatives when each alternative will deprive them of a substantial, constitutionally-protected 
21  aspect of liberty. See United States v. Jackson, 390 U.S. 570 (1968); cf. New York v. United States, 
22  505 U.S. 144, 176 (1992). 
23  255.  In invading these fundamental constitutional rights, Defendants have articulated no 
24  substantial governmental interest and have failed adequately to tailor their action to promote any 
25  legitimate interest they may have. Nowhere in the notices terminating the TPS designations for El 
26  Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan, for example, have Defendants identified 
27  any risk to the interests of the United States that would follow from allowing the school-aged U.S. 
28 
68 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 72 of 75
 
1  citizen children to remain in the United States with their TPS holder parents until the children 
2  reach the age of majority. 
3  256.  Similarly, nowhere in the notices terminating the TPS designations for El Salvador, 
4  Haiti, Honduras, Nepal, Nicaragua, and Sudan has the Secretary adequately explained the 
5  Secretary’s new interpretation of the governing statute, reconciled it with the Secretary’s 
6  longstanding prior interpretation, or justified its extraordinary invasion of the U.S. citizen 
7  children’s constitutional rights. 
8  257.  Plaintiffs and Individual Plaintiffs’ class will suffer irreparable injury resulting from 
9  the termination of the TPS designations. 
10

1  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
2  Individual Plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similar situated, ask this Court to 
3  grant the following relief:  
4  1.  Declare that Defendants’ termination of the TPS designations for El Salvador, Haiti, 
5  Honduras, Nepal, Nicaragua and Sudan, was unconstitutional under the Due Process 
6  Clause of the Fifth Amendment and unlawful under the Administrative Procedure Act; 
7  2.  Declare  that  the  Defendants’  interpretation  of  the  TPS  statute  to  preclude 
8  consideration of intervening conditions was legally erroneous in violation of the 
9  Administrative Procedure Act.  
10  3.  Declare that Defendants’ refusal to consider intervening conditions in making TPS 
11  decisions was arbitrary, capricious, and contrary to law in violation of the APA 
12  because it represented a sudden, unacknowledged, and unexplained departure from 
13  decades of decision-making practices and ordinary procedures. Further, Defendants 
14  changed their policy without taking into account the serious reliance interests that 
15  their prior policy had engendered. 
16  4.  Enjoin and restrain all Defendants, and their officers, agents, servants, employees, 
17  attorneys, and all other persons who are in active concern or participation with any of 
18  them, from terminating TPS for any TPS holders protected by this Court’s preliminary 
19  injunction who registers for a TPS extension by June 30, 2024, the last date at which 
20  TPS is protected pursuant to the preliminary injunction;   
21  5.  Enjoin and restrain all Defendants, and their officers, agents, servants, employees, 
22  attorneys, and all other persons who are in active concern or participation with any of 
23  them,  from  requiring  or  collecting  an  initial  application  fee  for  Form  I-821, 
24  Application for Temporary Protected Status, from any TPS applicant whose TPS 
25  status was preserved by this Court’s preliminary injunction in Ramos or stay of 
26  proceedings in Bhattarai; 
27  6.  Order Defendants to take all steps necessary to return any initial application fee for 
28  Form I-821, Application for Temporary Protected Status, paid by TPS holders whose 
70 
AMENDED COMPLAINT – CASE NO. 3:18-CV-1554-EMC 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 204   Filed 08/24/23   Page 74 of 75
 
1  status was preserved by this Court’s preliminary injunction in Ramos or stay of 
2  proceedings in Bhattarai pursuant to the April 19, 2022 designation of Sudan for TPS 
3  or the August 3, 2021 designation of Haiti for TPS; 
4  7.  Alternatively, certify this case as a class action lawsuit as proposed herein, appoint 
5  Individual Plaintiffs Rilya Salary, S.S., and G.D.P. as class representatives of their 
6  class and the undersigned counsel as class counsel; 
7  8.  And enjoin and restrain all Defendants, and their officers, agents, servants, employees, 
8  attorneys, and all other persons who are in active concern or participation with any of 
9  them, from rescinding the immigration status of those TPS holders who have school-
10  aged U.S. citizen children for so long as the children remain age five to eighteen; 
11  9.  Grant an award of attorneys’ fees and costs; and 
12  10. Grant any other and further relief that this Court may deem fit and proper. 
13

N 18  Plaintiffs filed suit in 2018 and 2019, challenging the Trump administration’s termination of the 
19  TPS designations for those six countries.  In October 2018, this Court granted Plaintiffs a 
20  preliminary injunction.  The government appealed and prevailed, but, subsequently, in February 
21  2023, the Ninth Circuit granted Plaintiffs’ petition for an en banc hearing.  Shortly before the en 
22  banc hearing, the government announced that it would be rescinding the 2017 and 2018 
23  terminations of the TPS designations for El Salvador, Honduras, Nepal, and Nicaragua.  By that 
24  time the government had already newly designated Haiti and Sudan for TPS.  The government 
25  thereafter voluntarily moved to dismiss its appeal with the Ninth Circuit , and the Ninth Circuit 
26  granted that relief. 
27  Following the appellate proceedings, Plaintiffs took the position before this Court that the 
28  case was still not moot.  The Court allowed Plaintiffs to file a consolidated amended complaint.  

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 222   Filed 12/28/23   Page 2 of 20
 
1  The government then filed the pending motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.  
2  The government primarily argues that the case should be dismissed based on mootness, whether 
3  Plaintiffs are arguing (1) that the Trump administration’s TPS terminations were improper or (2) 
4  that the government has improperly charged TPS holders from Haiti or Sudan a $50 registration 
5  fee. 
6  Having considered the parties’ briefs and accompanying submissions, as well as the oral 
7  argument of counsel, the Court hereby GRANTS the motion to dismiss. 
8  I.  FACTUAL & PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND 
9  In the operative class action amended complaint (“CAC”), Plaintiffs allege as follows. 
10  Congress established the TPS program through the Immigration Act of 1990.  See CAC ¶ 
11  46.  The TPS statute is codified at 8 U.S.C. § 1254a.  See id.  Under the program, foreign nationals 
12  of designated countries are given lawful immigrant status because they cannot safely return home.  
 
tr ain
uoro 13  Specifically, the Attorney General has the authority to issue a TPS designation based on certain 
Cfil
 tcaC 14  criteria – e.g., an ongoing armed conflict or an environmental disaster such as an earthquake or 
irts fo
iD tc 15  flood.  See id. ¶ 47; see also 8 U.S.C. § 1254a(b)(1).  An initial designation lasts between 6 to 18 
 sir
etatsiD 16  months.  See CAC ¶ 48; see also 8 U.S.C. § 1254a(b)(2).  “Before the designation can become 
t
S d nr
ee 17  effective, the Secretary [of Homeland Security] must publish a notice in the Federal Register that 
tinhtr
Uo
N 18  includes, among other things, a statement of findings, the effective date of the designation, and a 
19  tally of eligible foreign nationals.”  CAC ¶ 48; see also 8 U.S.C. § 1254a(b) (“A designation of a 
20  foreign state . . . under this paragraph shall not become effective unless notice of the designation 
21  (including a statement of the findings under this paragraph and the effective date of the 
22  designation) is published in the Federal Register.  In such notice, the Attorney General shall also 
23  state an estimate of the number of nationals of the foreign state designated who are (or within the 
24  effective period of the designation are likely to become) eligible for temporary protected status 
25  under this section and their immigration status in the United States.”).   
26  Thereafter, the Secretary engages in a periodic review of TPS designations.  See id. ¶ 51; 
27  see also 8 U.S.C. § 1254a(b)(3).  The statute provides in relevant part as follows: 
 
28  (A)   Periodic review.  At least 60 days before end of the initial

subparagraph (including the basis for the determination).

(d)(3), but shall not be effective earlier than 60 days after the

tr ain most recent previous extension under subparagraph (C).

Uo
N 18  Id. 
19  In 2017 and 2018, the Trump administration terminated the TPS designations of four 
20  countries: (1) Sudan; (2) Haiti; (3) Nicaragua; and (4) El Salvador.  See id. ¶¶ 2, 8.  The 
21  termination was based on a new interpretation of the TPS statute.  According to Plaintiffs, 
 
22  DHS abandoned a long-established practice under which it 
considered all current conditions – including intervening events – in 
23  deciding whether to extend or terminate a country’s TPS 
designation.  In its place, DHS adopted a new, narrow practice in 
24  which DHS considers only whether the original conditions that 
initially gave rise to the TPS designation persist, and only those 
25  ongoing harms directly tied to those original conditions. 
26  Id. ¶ 62 (emphasis added).  The new interpretation was “motivated by intentional race- and 
27  national-origin-based animus against individuals from what former President Trump referred to as 
28  ‘shithole countries.’ i.e., non-white, non-European immigrants.”  Id. ¶ 10. 
3 

Case 3:18-cv-01554-EMC   Document 222   Filed 12/28/23   Page 4 of 20
 
1  In October 2018, this Court granted Plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, barring 
2  enforcement of the decisions to terminate TPS for Sudan, Haiti, El Salvador, and Nicaragua.  See 
3  id. ¶ 153; see also Docket No. 128 (order).  The government appealed to the Ninth Circuit.  
4  However, pending appeal, it agreed “to issue periodic Federal Register notices automatically 
5  extending TPS status and employment authorization for TPS holders from El Salvador, Haiti, 
6  Nicaragua, and Sudan . . . for at least nine months at a time.”  CAC ¶ 156.  The government later 
7  agreed to the same procedure for Nepal and Honduras, after it was announced their TPS 
8  designations would also be terminated.1  See id. ¶ 158-59; see also id. ¶ 161 (alleging that 
9  “Defendants have issued five Federal Register notices automatically extending TPS status and 
10  employment authorization for TPS holders protected by this Court’s orders”). 
11  In September 2020, a Ninth Circuit panel reversed this Court’s decision granting a 
12  preliminary injunction.  Plaintiffs sought rehearing en banc.  See id. ¶ 160. 
 
tr ain
uoro 13  In January 2021, President Biden took office.  Shortly thereafter, Plaintiffs asked the Ninth 
Cfil
 tcaC 14  Circuit to stay proceedings on their petition, “citing President Biden’s stated intention to take swift 
irts fo
iD tc 15  action on TPS.”  Id. ¶ 164. 
 sir
etatsiD 16  In June 2021, the parties jointly moved the case to be referred to the Ninth Circuit’s 
t
S d nr
ee 17  mediation program.  See id. ¶ 166.   
tinhtr
Uo
N 18  In August 2021,  
 
19  DHS published a Federal Register notice designating Haiti for TPS 
for 18 months . . . . The Federal Register notice cites human rights 
20  violations and abuses by law enforcement officials and non-state 
actors; serious security concerns, including violent criminal gangs; a 
21  dire economic situation, including a poverty rate of nearly 60%; a 
weak healthcare system suffering from ‘the lingering impact of the 
22  2010 earthquake and Hurricane Matthew in 2016’; and the impact of 
the COVID-19 pandemic.

3  In the pending motion, the government argues that Plaintiffs’ case is now moot.  Because
